text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.1.8, Appeals Function, Employee Tax Compliance.
Added new IRM 8.1.8.1, Program Scope and Objectives, and related sections containing internal control information required by IRM 1.11.2.2.5, Address Management and Internal Controls.
Table of Contents
Tax Compliance
page (

) Purpose: This IRM section provides guidance to ensure that Employee Tax Compliance (ETC) cases are properly identiﬁed and routed to designated and employees and locations to safeguard information in this highly sensitive of case. Speciﬁcally, IRM

: a. Establishes the scope of Appeals’ consideration of ETC cases b. Describes Appeals procedures speciﬁc to ETC cases c. Describes the steps to identify employees designated to handle ETC cases throughout the Appeals process (

) Audience: The primary users of this IRM section are Appeals employees handling ETC cases to include Account and Processing Support (APS) employees, Appeals Team Managers (ATMs), Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs), Appeals Tax Computation Team Managers (ATCTMs), and Tax tation Specialists (TCS). (
) Policy Owner: Director, Case and Operations Support (
) Program Owner: Director, Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PPQ&A) (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM Section. (

) Appeals’ mission is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes this mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. See IRC Section
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights, Pub
, Taxpayer Bill of Rights, and IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission. (
) Standards for Ethical Conduct,
C.F.R. Part

) states that employees of the Executive Branch of the U.S. Government “shall satisfy in good faith their obligations as citizens, including all just ﬁnancial obligations, especially those—such as Federal, State, or local taxes—that are imposed law.” (

) When IRS employees accept their position, they agree to safeguard the public’s trust and to administer the Federal tax law fairly and with integrity by setting the example of full tax compliance. Any failure on the part of an IRS employee to comply fully with the Federal tax laws undermines the conﬁdence in the Service’s commitment to administer the tax system fairly ethically. (

) The standards of ethical conduct for IRS employees make ETC cases highly sensitive in nature. The outcome of the case may initiate a conduct tion resulting in adverse action. Employees involved in processing or working these cases must ensure that this sensitive information is safeguarded. (

The standards of ethical conduct for IRS employees make ETC cases highly sensitive in nature. The outcome of the case may initiate a conduct investiga- tion resulting in adverse action. Employees involved in processing or working these cases must ensure that this sensitive information is safeguarded.
) IRS Restructuring and Reform Act (RRA) of
- Section

, of Employment for Misconduct, provides for the Commissioner’s IRS employees for certain acts or omissions that include the willful failure timely ﬁle a tax return as required or the willful understatement of Federal liability, unless the failure or understatement is due to reasonable cause not to willful neglect. (
) Per IRM
, Policy Statement

, the public expects the highest degree of integrity in tax matters on the part of all Service employees. To end, the Service established a comprehensive employee tax compliance program. A coordinated effort is required to ensure the comparability the treatment of Service employees and tax compliance issues and the treatment of all taxpayers and tax compliance matters. See IRM Responsible Official to Oversee Program. (
) The Director, Case and Operations Support, is the executive responsible Appeals’ policy and procedural guidance for working employment tax ance cases. (
) The Director, Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PPQ&A) is the manager responsible for program oversight. (
) The assigned Policy analyst shown on the IRM Product Catalog page as originator is responsible for the content and updates to this IRM Section. (
) PPQ&A provides trend and data analyses and detailed summary reports Appeals, as needed. Reports (

) Upon receipt of the case, Atlanta APS will: a. Acknowledge receipt of the case by returning to Compliance a signed Form

b. Card the case on ACDS c. Assign the case based on the pre-approved assignment list d. Send an encrypted message to the Appeals Team Manager (ATM), the Appeals Technical Employee (ATE), and the designated Appeals Policy Program Analyst notifying them of the case assignment e. Mail the case ﬁle directly to the ATE assigned to work the case Note: Due to the sensitive nature of these cases, they can only be assigned to Appeals employees pre-approved to work them. Access the list of Appeals employees from the Appeals Intranet Home Page > Case tab > Employee Tax Compliance Designated Appeals Employees. (
) The Appeals Policy Program Analyst updates the case in ACDS to designate as an employee audit case using the Special Project Update menu. Cases generally coded as A
to denote employee audit. Other codes may be used special projects as needed. This code is not visible on the ACDS CASES screen. (

) Employee Tax Compliance (ETC) cases involve an examination or collection activity of Internal Revenue Service (IRS) employees. When a taxpayer employee does not agree with Compliance’s ﬁndings, they have the option of exercising their right to an appeal. Appeals is not involved in potential ary actions. When working ETC cases, Appeals limits its scope to: a. Facts of the case b. Applicable law c. Appropriate resolution

Due to the sensitive nature of these cases, they can only be assigned to Appeals employees pre-approved to work them. Access the list of designated Appeals employees from the Appeals Intranet Home Page > Case Routing tab > Employee Tax Compliance Designated Appeals Employees.

The Appeals Policy Program Analyst updates the case in ACDS to designate it as an employee audit case using the Special Project Update menu. Cases are generally coded as A1 to denote employee audit. Other codes may be used for special projects as needed. This code is not visible on the ACDS CASES

Employee Tax Compliance (ETC) cases involve an examination or collection activity of Internal Revenue Service (IRS) employees. When a taxpayer employee does not agree with Compliance’s ﬁndings, they have the option of exercising their right to an appeal. Appeals is not involved in potential ary actions. When working ETC cases, Appeals limits its scope to:
Appeals (

) Only designated ATEs, ATMs, and TCS employees are assigned these highly sensitive cases. The ATE works the ETC case following the tax law and dural guidance to the same extent that applies to other taxpayers, based on the work stream and case type. See IRM

, Installment Agreements, information applicable to IRS employees. Priority treatment is given to the extent possible. Note: Due to the sensitive nature of these cases, Appeals employees are prohib- ited from identifying the case in the “Notes” section of ACDS or in any way as an employee audit case. (
) The ATE ensures the complete case is sent for “review and approval” to a ignated ATM reviewer. See “Note” in IRM

) e) regarding designated employees. The ATE sends an encrypted email notifying the designated ATM reviewer that a ﬁle is being forwarded for review. In the email, include the Statute Expiration Date on the case and any other priorities. (
) There are designated ATM reviewers for the examination and collection work streams. The ATM will: a. Review and approve the case b. Return the approved closed case to Atlanta APS [See IRM

) routing information] c. Input the ACAPDATE on ACDS Note: If the ATE is not a direct report to the ATM Reviewer, then the ATM may need to send a secure email to the assigned ATM for the ACAP date be entered. (
) If APS assistance is needed to reverse a premature assessment for a docketed case, forward the appropriate documents to Atlanta APS to abate premature assessment. (
) If Compliance’s assistance is needed, follow the normal procedures that for a non-IRS employee case. (

) IRS employees have both a federal employee indicator and an IRS indicator on their accounts. IRS’s computer systems identify IRS employee an cases by the following literals: • Bal. Due — IRS EMPLOYEE • ENMOD — IRS- EMP • TXMOD — IRS- EMP • IMFOL — IRS EMPL (
) “IRS employee” coded cases are designated as:
- Primary taxpayer is an IRS employee
- Secondary taxpayer is an IRS employee
- Both taxpayers are IRS employees Note: For additional information, see IRM
, IRS Employee Cases, and Exhibit

) If a computation is needed, the ATE will complete Form
, Request for TCS Service, in “APGolf” and select the designated Appeals Tax Team Manager (ATCTM) in the drop down list. See “Note” in IRM
) regarding designated employees. On Form
under “Priority Indications”, enter “Employee Tax Case” in the “Other” ﬁeld and check the box. (
) The designated ATCTM will assign the case to an approved TCS, who will prepare the settlement computation or Notice of Deﬁciency, and forward them to the ATE. (
) Per IRM

, Working ETC Cases, the ATE works the ETC case following the tax law and procedural guidance to the same extent as for other For an installment agreement with an IRS employee, include a completed Form
, Payroll Deduction Agreement. See IRM
), IRS Cases. (
) The approved case will be forwarded to Atlanta APS, who will process, suspend, and/or route the case following normal procedures based on the work stream and case type. See exception in paragraph (
For Examination-sourced cases, Atlanta APS will forward the closed case to Baltimore Technical Services at the following address:
